In order to keep in subjec- tion a country difficult of access, and at the same time a granary of corn; where the genius of the people (a), deeply tinged with superstition, was ever wavering, and prone to change; where there was no plan of regular government, and, by consequence, no respect paid to the civil magistrate; it was the policy of Augustus to retain the administration, like a mystery of state, in his own hands, and under his own cabinet council. In the present juncture (b), Ti- berius Alexander, a native of the country, was intrusted with the government of the province.
